content: Little strong man defeats giant in race.

*Type 328; A. Stender-Petersen Acta Jutlandica VI (1934)
166ff.; Irish myth: Cross; English: Child II 35ff.; Icelandic: *Boberg; Spanish
Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: Rotunda; Japanese: Anesaki 311; Jewish:
Neuman, I Samuel 17:23 (David and Goliath); N. A. Indian (Southern Paiute,
Shivwits): Lowie JAFL XXXVII 150 No. 17; Guatamala Indian (Quiche): Alexander
Lat. Am. 168ff.; Tuamotu: Beckwith Myth 476.
child: Poorly-armed hero overcomes well-armed by strategy.
Little innocent girl is able to drive giant out of land.

content: Little fishes escape from the net.

The large are caught. *Type 253; *BP III 355; Wienert FFC
LVI 66 (ET 299), 113 (ST 240); Halm Aesop No. 26.

Offended rats gnaw saddle girths of king’s horses so that
he is defeated in battle.

Hummingbird can see fowler’s net; eagle is caught in spite
of his boasts of good eyesight.

*Pauli
(ed. Bolte) No. 290; Rumanian: Schullerus FFC LXXVIII No. 254*.
Mice escape into their holes; weasels cannot follow them.

Wienert FFC LVI 48 (ET 65), *113 (ST 241); Halm Aesop No.
291.

Bride asks suitors what they have to offer her. Poor youth who has nothing but
love to offer gets her. India: Thompson-Balys.
Mouse stronger than wall, wind, mountain.

*DeCock Volkssage 31ff.;
BP I 148 n. 2; Wesselski Mönchslatein 82 No. 75; Chauvin II 97 No. 55; Archiv
f. d. Studium d. neueren Sprachen LXXXI 265; Germania II 481; Basset RTP VII
394ff.; Basset Contes Berbères 95f; *Bødker Exempler 297 No. 60.--Spanish: Keller,
Espinosa III Nos. 275--277; Jewish: Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys; Japanese:
Ikeda.
child:
Mosquitoes sting King Pharaoh and show they are stronger
than the man who cannot escape them.
Reed pricks and drives away dog that urinates on it.

content:
Frog, tortoise, fish each tell of how long they expect to
live.

Frog alone does not expect to live
to a hundred and ten years and alone escapes fisherman’s net. India:
Thompson-Balys.
Slow flying swan lasts longer than speedy crow in flying.

Goldsmith gives money to one who addressed him as friend
(the goldsmith had no friends because he has cheated everybody.)
Priest who gives mild penances succeeds where others fail.

Scala Celi 48a No. 272; Alphabet No. 183; Herbert III 505,
570; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Gives everyone the same measure of wit, so that the smaller are more clever
than the large. Wienert FFC LVI 35; Halm Aesop No. 150.

child: Bird flies into large animal‘s ear and kills him.

*Type 228; *BP II 437; Japanese: Ikeda; Indonesia:
DeVries’s list No. 115.
Mouse runs into buffalo‘s ear and overcomes him.
Mouse torments bull who cannot catch him.
Fox burns tree in which eagle has nest.

Revenges theft of cub. Herbert III 12; *Crane Vitry 194
No. 144.
Revenges theft of her young. *Crane Vitry 194 No. 143.
Lark causes elephant to fall over precipice.

Chauvin II 81 No. 1; India: Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth:
Malalasekera II 771; Japanese: Ikeda.

Elephant killed by mouse who runs up open end of trunk to
head and there smears poison over his brain.
Insects worry large animal to despair or death.

Wienert FFC LVI *48 (ET 76), 120 (ST 301); Spanish:
Espinosa Jr. Nos. 187, 209; Japanese: Ikeda; Indonesia: DeVries’s list Nos.
132, 137.

Eagle at last goes to the sky and lays eggs in Zeus’s lap.
The dungbeetle causes Zeus to shake his apron and break the eggs. Wienert FFC
LVI *51 (ET 106), 77 (ET 432), 113 (ST 237), 114 (ST 249); Halm Aesop No. 7.
Fish pricks monster with fins and defeats him.
Falcon attacks eagle repeatedly and defeats him.

Hedgehog defeats tiger by jumping into tiger‘s mouth and
tormenting him.
Small animals dupe larger into trap.

content:
Survives him and inherits property. Africa (Fang): Tessman
191ff.

child:
Rain also tries unsuccessfully like wind. India:
Thompson-Balys.

Sun cursed by man for its burning rays, wind for its hot
breath, but moon is blessed for its soft, cool, and beautiful light.

Mildness triumphs over violence: queen advises husband to
use kindness to enemies.

This wins them
over where war failed. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Saint uses kind words to pagan priest who has just smitten
a Christian.

This causes pagan to repent.
Conversion follows. Spanish Exempla: Keller.
